Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 06:30AM jeskachi wrote: I'm not an expert but that doesn't seem right to me.  Why would stretch marks matter?  If she needs extra skin on the reconstructed breast stretch marks might show, but do they complicate healing?  I've never heard of that.  The arimidex slowing the cancer until surgery sounds odd to me too.  Why is a plastic surgeon prescribing arimidex?  Shouldn't a breast surgeon or oncolologist be overseeing that? There might be other things at play here that she hasn't told you, but it all seems a little odd to me. Maybe she should seek a second opinion--on everything.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2010 01:38PM jeskachi wrote: I've always wondered this about the breast conservation mentality... why do doctors care whether you have lumpectomy or mastectomy?  Breast tissue is not vital to your health, so it can't be a physical health concern. Surgery is surgery. Radiation is no picnic (so I've heard), and can have long-term consequences that simple mastectomy won't. As for psychological health... who's to say that having a disfigured breast from lumpectomy isn't going to be more traumatic than total mastectomy? Or that having one natural breast and one reconstructed breast is better than having 2 reconstructed breasts?  Personally, the thought of going through life lopsided or noticeably different on one side was much scarier to me than doing both at one time.There's a loss associated with not having natural nipples, yes, but are doctors really that concerned about our sex lives? I just don't get it.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 03:47PM jeskachi wrote: These do show in thin shirts, yes, so I've been wearing thick sweaters and cardigans.  It's not horrible, but it's noticeable without a few layers on.  It might be less noticeable with a more padded bra, but I hate wearing padded bras.
Posts.Title: how did your PS protect your new nipples after recon surgery? Laurie08 mtks

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 03:48PM jeskachi wrote: oh, one more thing... other people have mentioned using stacked callous pads. They won't work for me at this point because my nipples are still too big around, but they might work for you.
Posts.Title: how did your PS protect your new nipples after recon surgery? Laurie08 mtks

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 03:34PM jeskachi wrote: I've been wearing Simplisse breast shells. They're for nursing mothers with sore nipples.  Simplisse has the lowest projection of all the similar shells out there.  They're silicone, so you can boil them to sterilize them.  And the part that goes against your skin is soft silicone, so you can easily make the hole bigger if you need it.  I wear it with gauze between it and my skin because my incisions are still healing, I just cut a hole in the gauze for my nipples.  It stays in place inside your bra.
Posts.Title: how did your PS protect your new nipples after recon surgery? Laurie08 mtks
